title: 105_s1453
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace Act". It includes findings related to workplace fairness. The "National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace Act" acknowledges the increasing trend of part-time workers with limited benefits and protections. It raises concerns about the impact of part-time employment on wage levels, benefits, earning potential, and productivity. The Act proposes the establishment of a Federal commission to study these issues. The National Commission on Fairness in the Workplace is established with 9 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives for the life of the Commission. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of its establishment. The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives, must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of establishment. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairperson, with a majority of members forming a quorum for business transactions. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives, must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of establishment. Subsequent meetings will be called by the Chairperson, with a majority of members forming a quorum for business transactions. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from among its members. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on the impact of part-time employment in the United States, including trends in job creation, relationship to wage levels and benefits, and differences in treatment between part-time and full-time workers. A report on the study must be submitted to the President and Congress within 12 months of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from Federal agencies, and take necessary actions to fulfill its duties under this Act. Additionally, the Commission has authority over personnel matters. The Commission members receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are allowed travel expenses while away from home. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation should not exceed the rate for a position at level V of the Executive Schedule. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint personnel without following civil service laws, and may detail government employees without reimbursement. The Chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint personnel under specific rates not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level V of the Executive Schedule. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Commission to carry out the Act's purposes, with funds remaining available until expended. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report.
